intro: Otopetalum tunguraguae, commonly known as the Tunguragua mallow, is a flowering plant native to the Andean region of South America. It belongs to the Malvaceae family and is characterized by its showy, pink to purple bract-like flowers that resemble petals. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded environments, such as cloud forests, where it thrives in the cool, humid climate. Its leaves are ovate and covered in fine hairs, while its stems are woody and often branched. Otopetalum tunguraguae is of interest to botanists due to its unique floral structure and limited distribution.
